contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Village Weaver | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{IUCN|id=106008526 |title=''Ploceus cucullatus'' |assessors=[[BirdLife International]] |version=2012.1 |year=2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> | image = Ploceus_cucullatus_040216_1rw.jpg | image_width = | image_caption = Female from [[Réunion]] Island | image2 = Ploceus cucullatus male.jpg | image2_width = | image2_caption = A male of the southern population | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Passeriformes]] | familia = [[Ploceidae]] | genus = ''[[Ploceus]]'' | species = '''''P. cucullatus''''' | binomial = ''Ploceus cucullatus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Statius Muller|Müller]], 1766) }} The ''' Village Weaver ''' (''Ploceus cucullatus''), also known as the '''Spotted-backed Weaver''' or '''Black-headed Weaver''' (the latter leading to easy confusion with ''[[Ploceus melanocephalus|P. melanocephalus]]''), is a species of [[bird]] found in much of [[sub-Saharan Africa]]. It has also been [[Introduced species|introduced]] to [[Hispaniola]], [[Mauritius]] and [[Réunion]]. This often abundant species occurs in a wide range of open or semi-open [[habitat]]s, including [[woodland]]s and human habitation, and frequently forms large noisy colonies in towns, villages and hotel grounds. [[File:weavernests2.jpg|left|160px|thumb|Village Weaver colony in [[The Gambia]]. The nests are the round suspended objects.]] This [[Ploceidae|weaver]] builds a large coarsely woven [[bird nest|nest]] made of grass and leaf strips with a downward facing entrance which is suspended from a branch in a tree. 2-3 [[bird egg|eggs]] are laid. This is a colonial breeder, so many nests may hang from one tree. The Village Weaver is a stocky 15–17 cm bird with a strong conical bill and dark reddish eyes. In the northern part of its range, the breeding male has a black head edged by chestnut (typically most distinct on the nape and chest). Towards the southern part of its [[range (biology)|range]], the amount of black and chestnut diminish, and the breeding males of the southernmost [[subspecies]] only have a black face and throat, while the nape and crown are yellow. In all [[subspecies]] the breeding male has a black [[beak|bill]], black and yellow upperparts and wings, and yellow underparts. The non-breeding male has a yellow head with an olive crown, grey upperparts and whitish underparts. The wings remain yellow and black. The adult female has streaked olive upperparts, yellow and black wings, and pale yellow underparts. Young birds are like the female but browner on the back. Village Weaver feeds principally on seeds and grain, and can be a crop pest, but it will readily take insects, especially when feeding young, which partially redresses the damage to agriculture. The calls of this bird include harsh buzzes and chattering. <gallery> File:Ploceus cucullatus-20030928.jpg|Building a nest File:Ploceus cucullatus -The Gambia -male-8.jpg|Male in non-breeding plumage File: Ploceidae_-_Ploceus_cucullatus.jpg|Female or non-breeding male Ploceus cucullatus nigriceps (male acrobat) 1.jpg|Male starting a nest </gallery> ==References== {{Reflist}}<!-- AnimalBiodiversityAndConservation26:45.
